|mapsize=260px |notice=IPA }} 'Occitan' (; Oxford Advanced Learner's
Dictionary, 7th edition, 2005. ; ), Regional pronunciations: occitan =
. known also as 'Lenga d'Ã²c' by its native speakers (; ), is a Romance
language spoken in southern France, Italy's Occitan Valleys, Monaco, and
Catalonia's Val d'Aran: the regions sometimes known unofficially as Occitania.
It is also spoken in the linguistic enclave of Guardia Piemontese (Calabria,
Italy). Occitan is a descendant of the spoken Latin language of the Roman
Empire, as are languages such as Catalan, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Romanian
and Sardinian. It is an official language in Catalonia (known as Aranese in Val
d'Aran). As stated in its Statute of Autonomy approved. See Article 6.5 in
the [http://www.parlament-cat.net/porteso/estatut/estatut_angles_100506.pdf Parlament-
cat.net], text of the 2006 Statute of Catalonia (PDF) Occitan's closest
relative is Catalan. Smith and Bergin. Old ProvenÃ§al Primer, p. 9.
Since September 2010, the Parliament of Catalonia has considered Aranese Occitan
to be the officially preferred language for use in the Val d'Aran.

Across history, the terms [[Limousin dialect|Limousin]] (occitan: lemosin),
[[Gascon dialect|Gascon]], [[Languedocien dialect|Languedocien]], and later
[[ProvenÃ§al dialect|ProvenÃ§al]] (Occitan: provenÃ§al, provenÃ§au or prouvenÃ§au)
have been used as traditional synonyms for the whole of Occitan; nowadays,
âProvenÃ§alâ is mainly understood as an Occitan dialect spoken in
Provence.

The long-term survival of Occitan is in question. According to the UNESCO Red
Book of Endangered Languages, [http://www.unesco.org/culture/languages-
atlas/index.php Languages Atlas, UNESCO] four of the six major dialects of
Occitan (ProvenÃ§al, Auvergnat, Limousin and Languedocien) are considered
severely endangered, while the remaining two (Gascon and Vivaro-Alpine) are
considered definitely endangered.
